medium: Pen, brown ink and light gray-brown wash
creditline: Bequest of Dan Fellows Platt, Class of 1895

makers.displaydate: 1615–1673; born Naples, Italy; died Rome, Italy
makers.displaymaker: Salvator Rosa, 1615–1673; born Naples, Italy; died Rome, Italy

texts.textentryhtml: One of the most horrific stories in Greek mythology involves the Titan Prometheus, who stole fire from the gods to give to humanity. As punishment, he was forever chained to a rock, where each day an eagle (a symbol of the god Zeus) would devour his perpetually regenerating liver. In preparation for his celebrated version of this subject, the Neapolitan painter Rosa made numerous rapid sketches such as this one, which features a close-up study of Prometheus’s anguished and contorted face.

bibliography.boilertext: Michael Mahoney, The drawings of Salvator Rosa, (New York; London: Garland Publishing, Inc., 1977).
bibliography.citation: Michael Mahoney, The drawings of Salvator Rosa, (New York; London: Garland Publishing, Inc., 1977)., 429, vol. 1; illus. no. 43.3, vol. 2

bibliography.boilertext: Felton Gibbons, Catalogue of Italian Drawings in The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1977).
bibliography.citation: Felton Gibbons, Catalogue of Italian Drawings in The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1977)., Vol. 1: p. 175, no. 533 (illustrated in Vol. 2 under the same catalog number)
